abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social assessment
            for the Gabon Natural Resources Management Development
            Policy Loan Project, which improves transparency and law
            enforcement for natural resource management, anticipates
            likely environmental impacts and discusses measures to
            mitigate them. The most significant potentially negative
            environmental impacts include overexploitation of non-wood
            forest products by installing badly controlled channels;
            increased solid waste and liquid effluents leading to
            increased river and aquifer pollution from industrial
            chemicals; uncontrolled forestry logging triggering losses
            of income leading to increased poaching, urban migration,
            and social conflicts; reduced biodiversity in freshwater
            ecosystems, possibly causing extinction of some species;
            uncontrolled exploitation of some aquatic species; and
            development of tourist activities incompatible with
            biodiversity conservation. Key social issues include crop
            destruction caused by wild animals; loss of access to land
            and traditional fishing grounds; loss of income
            opportunities; and uncertainty concerning the legal status
            of immigrants working in the sector. Measures to reduce
            these risks are as follows: Reinforce CENAP (the national
            environmental protection agency) to strengthen its role in
            controlling and analyzing pollution, especially regarding
            standards and laboratory protocols; monitor forest permits
            and reinforce the regulatory and legal framework; and
            provide training in protected areas management, solid waste
            and liquid effluent management, regulatory enforcement, and
            forest management.
